However, if the representative is unavailable, does not respond to repeated requests, and does not provide required items (other than items considered privileged), the IRS can bypass your representative and contact you directly. If a representative engages in conduct described above, the matter can be referred to the Office of Professional Responsibility for consideration of possible disciplinary action.

If you want to authorize your representative to receive copies of all notices and communications sent to you by the IRS, you must check the box that is provided under the representative's name and address.No more than two representatives may receive copies of notices and communications sent to you by the IRS. Do not check the box if you do not want copies of notices and communications sent to your representative(s).

If you have questions about a tax issue, need help preparing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, go to IRS.gov and find resources that can help you right away.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure your electronic payments are safe and secure. You can make electronic payments online, by phone, and from a mobile device using the IRS2Go app. Paying electronically is quick, easy, and faster than mailing in a check or money order. Go to IRS.gov/Payments to make a payment using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your individual tax bill or estimated tax payment directly from your checking or savings account at no cost to you. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online, by phone, and by mobile device. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Offered only when filing your federal taxes using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best option for businesses. Enrollment is required. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on the notice or instructions. Cash: You may be able to pay your taxes with cash at a participating retail store.

Go to IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of Form 1040X amended returns. Please note that it can take up to 3 weeks from the date you mailed your amended return for it to show up in our system and processing it can take up to 16 weeks.
Go to IRS.gov/Notices to find additional information about responding to an IRS notice or letter.

Keep in mind, many questions can be answered on IRS.gov without visiting an IRS Tax Assistance Center (TAC). Go to IRS.gov/LetUsHelp for the topics people ask about most. If you still need help, IRS TACs provide tax help when a tax issue can’t be handled online or by phone. All TACs now provide service by appointment so you’ll know in advance that you can get the service you need without long wait times. Before you visit, go to IRS.gov/TACLocator to find the nearest TAC, check hours, available services, and appointment options. Or, on the IRS2Go app, under the Stay Connected tab, choose the Contact Us option and click on “Local Offices.”
The IRS Video portal (IRSvideos.gov) contains video and audio presentations for individuals, small businesses, and tax professionals.

The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers and protects taxpayer rights. Our job is to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

We can help you resolve problems that you can’t resolve with the IRS. And our service is free. If you qualify for our assistance, you will be assigned to one advocate who will work with you throughout the process and will do everything possible to resolve your issue. TAS can help you if: Your problem is causing financial difficulty for you, your family, or your business, You face (or your business is facing) an immediate threat of adverse action, or You’ve tried repeatedly to contact the IRS but no one has responded, or the IRS hasn’t responded by the date promised.

We have offices in every state, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. Your local advocate’s number is in your local directory and at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Contact-Us. You can also call us at 1-877-777-4778.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes 10 basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Our Tax Toolkit at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov can help you understand what these rights mean to you and how they apply. These are your rights. Know them. Use them.

Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITCs) are independent from the IRS. LITCs represent individuals whose income is below a certain level and need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax collection disputes. In addition, clinics can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in different languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are offered for free or a small fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap or see IRS Publication 4134, Low Income Taxpayer Clinic List PDF.

Go to IRS.gov/Forms to view, download, or print all of the forms and publications you may need. You can also download and view popular tax publications and instructions (including the 1040 instructions) on mobile devices as an eBook at no charge. Or, you can go to IRS.gov/OrderForms to place an order and have forms mailed to you within 10 business days.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View the amount you owe, pay online or set up an online payment agreement. Access your tax records online. Review the past 18 months of your payment history. Go to IRS.gov/SecureAccess to review the required identity authentication process.

The fastest way to receive a tax refund is to combine direct deposit and IRS e-file. Direct deposit securely and electronically transfers your refund directly into your financial account. Eight in 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refund. IRS issues more than 90% of refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS can’t issue refunds before mid-February 2018, for returns that properly claimed the earned income credit (EIC) or the additional child tax credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion associated with these credits.

The quickest way to get a copy of your tax transcript is to go to IRS.gov/Transcripts. Click on either "Get Transcript Online" or "Get Transcript by Mail" to order a copy of your transcript. If you prefer, you can: Order your transcript by calling 1-800-908-9946. Mail Form 4506-T or Form 4506T-EZ (both available on IRS.gov).

Go to IRS.gov/Tools for the following. The Earned Income Tax Credit Assistant (IRS.gov/EIC) determines if you’re eligible for the EIC. The Online EIN Application (IRS.gov/EIN) helps you get an employer identification number. The IRS Withholding Calculator (IRS.gov/W4App) estimates the amount you should have withheld from your paycheck for federal income tax purposes. The First Time Homebuyer Credit Account Look-up (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer) tool provides information on your repayments and account balance. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/SalesTax) figures the amount you can claim if you itemize deductions on Schedule A (Form 1040), choose not to claim state and local income taxes, and you didn’t save your receipts showing the sales tax you paid.

The IRS doesn’t initiate contact with taxpayers by email or telephone to request personal or financial information. This includes any type of electronic communication, such as text messages and social media channels. Go to IRS.gov/IDProtection for information and videos. If your SSN has been lost or stolen or you suspect you’re a victim of tax-related identity theft, visit IRS.gov/ID to learn what steps you should take.

Go to IRS.gov/Refunds. Due to changes in the law, the IRS can’t issue refunds before mid-February 2018, for returns that properly claimed the EIC or the ACTC. This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion associated with these credits. Download the official IRS2Go app to your mobile device to check your refund status. Call the automated refund hotline at 1-800-829-1954.

Publication concerning the tax representative who represents a taxpayer before the IRS and who is authorized to file a tax return on behalf of the taxpayer. Generally, attorneys, certified public accountants (CPA), and insurance agents can represent taxpayers before the IRS. Insurance agents, actuaries, and certain other professionals, such as preparers of returns who are not authorized, may also represent taxpayers before the IRS. In special circumstances, other individuals, such as family members, non-professionals, and students, may represent taxpayers before the IRS.
Many times in the publication sector, terms such as “author” and “practitioner” are used, and their definitions are found in the Glosè, which is the publication sector's dictionary.

The person who is a Representative of a tax-exempt organization is not authorized to represent (a representative who is recognized) as a representative of a tax-exempt organization. Form 2848 can be used for this purpose.

People who prepare tax returns for individuals and businesses are required to file a Form 230 with the IRS. They must estimate the number of individuals they will represent and file a Form 230 with the IRS. They must estimate the number of individuals they will represent and file a Form 230 with the IRS.

A special relationship exists between a contributor and a tax-exempt organization, and the contributor is represented by the organization before the IRS, provided that the contributor presents identification that satisfies the IRS and, except in the case of a person, receives written authorization from the organization to represent the contributor. 1. A person. A person may represent themselves before the IRS without having to file a tax return or pay taxes. 2. A family member. A person may represent a family member. A family member includes a spouse, children, parents, siblings, or other relatives. 3. An officer. An officer of a corporation (including a parent corporation, a subsidiary, or another affiliated corporation), a partnership, or an organization may represent the corporation, partnership, or organization before the IRS. An officer of a government agency, or other entity, may represent that agency, or entity before the IRS in his or her capacity as an officer. 4. A partner. A general partner may represent a partnership before the IRS. A partner may, but is not required to, represent a partner, a corporation (including a parent corporation, a subsidiary, or another affiliated corporation), a partnership, or an organization. 5. An agent. An authorized agent may represent a principal. A principal may, but is not required to, represent a principal, a corporation (including a parent corporation, a subsidiary, or another affiliated corporation), a partnership, or an organization. 6. An administrator. An administrator (including a trustee, receiver, executor, representative of a person, agent, liquidator, or guardian) may represent a contributor and act on behalf of the contributor.

The regulations governing representation before the IRS are set forth in 31 CFR Subtitle A, Part 10 and are available at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals (in English). A lawyer, CPA, certified agent, certified public accountant, or certified tax preparer who is authorized to represent taxpayers before the IRS (referred to as a practitioner) must have a valid Social Security Number and must file an estimate form to be eligible for representation. In addition, a practitioner may not engage in conduct that is disreputable or that is incompetent or that fails to demonstrate good reputation. Furthermore, a practitioner must prepare returns that are in accordance with the applicable regulations and that are filed in a timely manner. There are specific provisions in the regulations that apply, set forth in Section 230 of the Internal Revenue Code: 1. Responsibilities and restrictions on representation (Section B of Section 230), and 2. Conduct that is considered incompetent or that is disreputable (Section C, Section 10.51 of Section 230).

If you represent yourself, you must file Form 2848, first page, and sign it with your name and date immediately below the signature line. At that time, you must also file with the IRS a copy of the return and notice of withdrawal from representation in the same form that is described in the Revocation of Representative section. If you do not have a copy of the return, you must file a declaration with the IRS to withdraw from representation, indicating the authority to withdraw, the dates of the withdrawal, the TIN, and the address (if known) of the representative. The representative must sign and date the declaration. The return must be registered with the CAF system within 130 days of the date it is received. If you authorize an agent to represent you after that date, you must file another Form 2848.

From January 1, 2018, the Tax Reform Act of 2015, which abolishes the tax credit for the purchase of a vehicle, eliminates the tax credit for the purchase of a vehicle and replaces it with a tax credit for the purchase of a new vehicle. According to Section 301.9100-22T of the Treasury Regulations, the tax credit for the purchase of a vehicle is replaced by a new tax credit for the purchase of a new vehicle starting on November 2, 2015, and before January 1, 2018.

A tax preparer is a representative of the IRS. If, however, the representative is not responsible for the tax return or an incorrect method is used, the IRS will contact the representative directly. In the event that the representative is unavailable, the IRS will contact the representative's supervisor. We provide information, education, and assistance to taxpayers and tax professionals. We also represent taxpayers before the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and other tax authorities.

The IRS will accept paper returns until January 31, 2019. If you file paper, you must mail your return to a local IRS office or to a post office box in your area. If you file electronically, you must file your return by February 15, 2019. If you file by mail, you must mail your return by February 15, 2019, or you will be subject to a penalty.

Because of the change in the law, the IRS cannot accept returns filed before February 2018 for the 2017 tax year, for the EITC or the ACTC. This applies to all returns filed, not just those filed by paid preparers who claim the credits.

How quickly can I get a copy of my tax return transcript from IRS.gov? Click on either “Get a Transcript from the Internet” or “Get a Return Not Filed by Mail” to order a copy of your return transcript. If you prefer, you can call 1-800-908-9946 to order a transcript by phone. You can also: File Form 4506-T or Form 4506T-EZ online (two forms available on IRS.gov).

The IRS.gov/HomeBuyer page provides information on home buying assistance and the IRS.gov/SalesTax page helps you calculate the amount of sales tax to claim on your tax return. You can claim the sales tax on your federal income tax return or on your state income tax return, depending on where you live. The IRS.gov/Refunds. Due to changes in the law, the IRS cannot issue refunds for returns filed before February 2018, for the EIC or ACTC.
